title: Wistman's Wood Walk Route

images.title: Paul Ansell / Wistmans Wood, Dartmoor, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: No photo can really do justice to this extraordinary place. The stunted oaks, the lichen and moss create a timeless and unique atmosphere - you really have to be in there to appreciate it.

images.title: Guy Wareham / Path to Wistmans Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Gorse flanked path to Wistmans Wood. Fingerpost at Crockern, Longaford and Littaford Tors in distance.

images.title: Martin Bodman / Dartmoor Forest: Wistman’s Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Wood Moss-covered granite boulders and stunted oaks

images.title: Martin Bodman / Dartmoor Forest: Wistman’s Wood, West Dart valley, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Dartmoor Forest: Wistmans Wood, West Dart valley. Above the trees the line of the Devonport Leat, cut in the 1790s, can be seen across the valley

images.title: Martin Bodman / Dartmoor Forest: edge of Wistman’s Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Dartmoor Forest, edge of Wistman's Wood. Looking across the West Dart valley with the line of the Devonport Leat up on Beardown Hill. The West Dart runs behind the oak trees. A red flag flies from a cairn on the horizon, warning of danger areas within military ranges

images.title: Nilfanion [CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The stunted Pedunculate Oaks (Quercus robur) inside Wistman's Wood during mid February.

images.title: alex jane from london, uk [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A remnant of ancient oak Quercus robur woodland

images.title: Derek Harper / Wistman's Wood and Littaford Tor, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Wistman's Wood and Littaford Tor. Looking across the West Dart from the northwestern corner of the square. The southern edge of the ancient oak wood crosses into this square; Littaford Tor is the small tor at top centre. (The larger Longaford Tor is out of square).

description: Enjoy a walk around this atmospheric forest and nature reserve in the Dartmoor National Park. It's an unusual place consisting of stunted oak trees with gnarled, tangled branches. There's also lots of spongy moss and over 100 types of lichen hanging from the branches. Other features include boulders covered with lichen and other trees such as rowan,  holly, hawthorn, hazel and eared-willow. This circular walk starts at a car park near the Two Bridges Hotel,  just to the south of the wood. You then pick up a footpath to the nature reserve before climbing Longaford Tor, where there are great views over Dartmoor. You return passing Littaford Tors and Crockern Tor. The wood is located just to the north of Princetown which is on the Dartmoor Way . The eery Lych Way ancient footpath also passes the northern tip of the woods. To extend your walking try our Two Bridges Dartmoor Walk . The long circular walk starts from the same location and visits the wood before heading east to visit the fascinating gunpowder mill remains and the lovely Bellever Forest .
